did.abstract: This item contains entries about prominent people (primarily accounts of their deaths); Philadelphia events and gossip; the Pennsylvania Hospital; questions for Meriwether Lewis on Indian physical history, medicine, morals, and religion; and his views on marriage, religion, physicians, etc. Also includes meeting with Captain Wells and Little Turtle; speculations on Indian skin color at the equator.

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: The commonplace book is better described as Benjamin Rush's diary of events from 1792. Rush recounts in great detail the spectacular failure of William Duer and other investors in Philadelphia and New York, noting the panic and uncertainty that swept elite society in those months. The second portion of the volume contains a range of Rushâ€™s thoughts and observations on society, making this portion more like a traditional commonplace book.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Biddle (pt. 3, no. 200; $2050.00) and accessioned, 1943 (1943 84467).

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Parts of this item are also available on microfilm (Film 813), and there is a photographic copy of this microfilm available in the repository.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This item was printed in George W. Corner, ed., "The Autobiography of Benjamin Rush: His Travels through Life, together with his Commonplace Book for 1789-1813," American Philosophical Society Memoirs 25 (1948).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Benjamin Rush was a physician, patriot, and humanitarian. He graduated from the College of New Jersey (Princeton), 1760, and from the University of Edinburgh, 1768. He was a member of the staff at the Pennsylvania Hospital and was a professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
